A wall hanging box for papers, forms, magazines, etc. (I will remove the WIP flag and post a picture once I've cut one for myself.) This design is a derivative of the press-fit box by Studio Ludens: http://magic-box.org/tool/?url=http://magic-box.org/designs/presentation/press_fit_box_with_desc.mbt&state=viewer

The included MBT file can be uploaded to http://magic-box.org to customize the layout. Using Magic-Box, you can change each of the following variables: height, width, depth, material thickness, number of tabs on each edge, size of the front opening, and size of the mounting hole. The included static SVG and DXF files were designed for ~3mm or 1/8" material and sized to fit 8.5"x11" sheets of paper. BUT, I have discovered that they are in fact a bit too small. I'll upload properly scaled files soon. Cut the design from your favorite material and glue together.

Using low quality setting, .3 mm layer height, no rafts or supports, and 10% infill, this boat would take about 16 hours to print on a MakeBot Replicator 2X

Please consider supporting me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/DanielNoree

The EMD SW 1500 is a American diesel switcher locomotive made by General Motors' Electro-Motive Division during the 60's and 70's. Some 800 were made and there are several still in serivce in the United States.

This 1:32 scale version of the EMD SW 1500 locomotive is part of "The OpenRailway Project" which is a Open Source initiative to bring more free model trains to the world. While having done several different 3Dprinting projects in the past i needed something with more attention todetail to 3Dprint. Since me and my dad had already built a garden railway (scale 1:32) it felt like a good idea to go for a train. I went to a model train store in Stockholm to discuss what train that might be suitable and after two or three cups of coffee i decided on the EMD SW1500.

Desingwork began by searching for specifications, drawings and pictures. While i din´t have very much luck finding the kind of drawings i initially hoped for (i did find a few) i had to rely heavily on different photos hence some details may be incorrect. Everything is 3D-printed but the handrail which is made from 1,5mm Aluminium welding rod. The are some details that need attention but basically you can print and assemble everyting if you want to own your very own 1:32 SW1500.

https://youtu.be/KFmzq_iMGYg
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/29jwnYZl5Cw" ></iframe>

title: Power cable holder for conduit based wiring

description.text: Was tired of digging for all of the plugs for my workbench tools so I designed a simple cable holder. Since my garage is all concrete, my electrical wiring is all conduit. This holder clips on to standard conduit and allows you to clip in 3 power cables. I left some spaces for you to write/stick/print labels for the cable holders. Printed at .3 layer height with 2 perimeters and 50% infill in ABS. I doubt PLA would work well with this design as some flex is required to fit thicker power cables.
If you rotate the model on to it's side, it will print without support and will have max strength

title: Prusa Mendel / Wades X-carriage Chatter Reducer

description.text:
An issue with the Prusa X-carriage + Wades extruder combo is that the overhanging motor causes the bushings opposite the motor to be very lightly loaded, and if the bushings are loose, it can cause that end to lift/drop on direction change and chatter. In order to tighten things up long enough to print better replacement parts, I designed this bit. It attaches to the carriage using the extruder mounting screw as a stud, so it only works with Makergear or similar hot ends that leave that screw open.
Original source file is from Solidworks 2011.

The part should be pretty self-explanatory.  Attach to extruder mounting screw with a locknut (a longer screw may need to be installed).  Adjust the locknut to provide sufficient tension.  Mine required some oil and runtime before it worked smoothly.

comments.text: Hi, just printed this, yet to test results. A note: I had to add 4 M4 washers between this and my carriage for the bolt to hold my extruder in place without clamping too hard on the smooth rods.

title: Filament Tube Holder for FlashForge Creator Pro

description.text:
This replaces the annoying and failure-prone filament tube clips on the back of the Creator Pro. It mounts using the four screws which hold the original tube clips. It's designed for the supplied 6mm OD tubing.

This is a modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:716246, which has 37 x 45mm mounting hole spacing and which does not fit the 32 x 45mm mounting holes on the Creator Pro.

1. Print this holder (3 perimeters, no supports, 25% or greater infill recc'd).

  2. Remove the four original filament tube clips (see photo).

  3. Unfasten the clip holding the wire bundle and move the wire bundle aside.

  4. Mount new filament tube holder using the original screws, and re-fasten wire bundle.

remixed_from.author: garyacrowellsr
remixed_from.title: Replicator MightyBoard Protection Part 2:  ESD Shielding

title: Replicator MightyBoard Protection: Part 3 - LCD Board

description.text:
From Part 1, we know that Replicator MightyBoards occasionally blow up. In that Thing and in Part 2 we corrected some problems and added some ESD protection. However we haven't done anything about the LCD board yet, so in this Thing we are going to address some of the issues there. There are several problems with the LCD board:
  • There is no ESD protection on any of the signal lines that are routed on the LCD ribbon cable.
  • The 3.3V regulator for the SD card and associated electronics is located on the MightyBoard - over a foot away on a poorly configured cable. This will result in very poor Power Integrity for these circuits.
  • There is no bulk or bypass capacitance for either the 3.3V or 5V supply lines at the LCD Board. This will result in very poor Power Integrity for all of the board circuits.
  • The level conversion for the SD card signals is 'iffy'; not something I'd do on a commercial product.
  • The organization of signals on the ribbon cable is very poor, resulting in poor Signal and Power Integrity.
  • Frankly, I'm surprised that it works at all.
    • So, the question is: Short of replacing the entire board, is there anything we can do to correct these issues? The answer is the LCD ESD board presented in this Thing. It's not going to be a perfect solution, but it's going to go a long way to make the LCD and SD card function a lot more reliably and add some ESD protection. The LCD ESD board plugs into the ribbon cable connector on the back of the LCD board, and the ribbon cable plugs into it. Here's what it does:
  • Adds ESD protection diodes to all signal lines.
  • Adds a local 3.3V regulator; the MightyBoard 3.3V regulator is ignored.
  • Adds bulk and bypass capacitance to the 5V and 3.3V rails. (Not a perfect location, but many times closer and more effective than the nothing that was there before.)
  • Adds proper level conversion of the SD card signals, and adds some termination components that may improve Signal Integrity.
  • Not much we can do about the cable organization, but we can add a simple clamp-on ferrite filter that might help some.

It's always a good idea to practice good ESD (Electro-Static Discharge) prevention around your Replicator at all times, regardless of any 'protection' you may have added: ESD Prevention
  • Avoid wearing clothing that generates static electricity.
  • Avoid placing your Replicator in a carpeted area.
  • When approaching your Replicator, touch something grounded before you touch the Replicator.
  • Be aware that low humidity conditions can increase ESD problems by a factor of 10X.
  • Also be aware that unpeeling just about any kind of tape generates an enormous static charge.
    • It wouldn't be a bad idea to wear an anti-static wrist band when working on your Replicator. (Note that so-called â€œwirelessâ€ or â€œcordlessâ€ anti-static wrist bands are a hoax, and are less than worthless for preventing ESD damage.) To be effective, the wrist band must be grounded. Prelude:
    In addition to this Thing, you really need some means of covering the back side of the LCD board. Unfortunately the excellent Replicator Keyboard Cover will not fit over the LCD board with the LCD ESD Thing attached. With no other alternative at the moment, I must recommend the Replicator Front Panel. Besides enclosing the LCD board, it makes the LCD much easier to read in most situations. In addition, I strongly recommend that you have installed the aluminum tape ESD shield described in Part 2. You can install this Thing without it, but I really believe it will be less effective. I will detail this alternative in the instructions. And of course, I would expect youâ€™ve installed the companion EndStopESD board from Part 1, though that isnâ€™t a requirement either. Materials:

  • You need an assembled LCD ESD board, or if you're building yourself, a bare board and the components listed in the bill-of-materials. With the included Gerber files, an order from OSHPark.com will get you three blank boards for about $7.50.

  • Ribbon cable. 4-to-6 conductors; you'll need about 6 inches (~24 inches without the Part 2 tape).

  • One crimp spade lug. (...and a ring lug without Part 2)

  • One M3 (or M4) screw and nut, and washer.
    • Tools:
  • If building from scratch, you will need a small soldering iron, fine wire solder, flux, and other normal soldering tools. A magnifier will probably help. The surface mount assembly on this board includes a few very fine pitch parts - not impossible to do by hand but you should have some SMT experience. (Oven or skillet reflow would be fine too, if you know that.)

  • Wire strippers/cutters.

  • Drill and bit appropriate for a 3mm (or 4mm) screw.

  • Allen wrench(s) to remove the LCD, Front Panel, Replicator bottom cover.

  • Crimp tool.

  • 25 - 40 Watt soldering iron, and solder.

  • Dremel tool with cutoff wheel, or some other implement of destruction to make the cuts cuts in the Replicator case as described below.
    • Skills:
    You will need to be able to solder a ground wire to the LCD ESD PCB. Make crimp connections. Drill a hole. Printing: Nothing to see here, move along. Installation:
    Sorry for the skipping around that follows, but I'm trying to accommodate two different possible Replicator configurations. You are in a maze of little twisty passages...

  • If you have not installed the ESD shield tape from Part 2, and don't intend to, skip to step 4, otherwise, prepare a 4 inch length of 4-to-8 conductor ribbon cable by putting a crimp lug on one end and twisting the leads of the other end together. Solder the end of this cable to one of the 'ESD GND' points on the LCD ESD board.

  • Drill a hole about 1/2 inch to the right of the case SD card slot, through the aluminum tape, so that it enters the build chamber. Insert a screw and washer into this hole, and lightly tighten a nut on the inside.

  • Connect the GND wire from the LCD ESD board to this new screw and tighten the nut. Skip to step 5.

  • Since you don't have the tape, you will need to make a long piece of ribbon cable that is soldered to the LCD ESD board at one of the 'ESD GND' points and running down through one of the corner cutouts and connecting with a ring lug to the ground screw that was installed in Part 1. Do not run this cable in parallel with the LCD ribbon cable.

  • If you have a Front Panel Thing, skip to step 8. Otherwise, this part is simple. Remove the Replicator Keyboard Cover if you have one. Unplug the ribbon cable to the LCD board.

  • Plug the LCD ribbon cable into the LCD ESD board. It is keyed and should only insert one way. Plug the board into the LCD board, in the orientation shown (i.e., it 'hangs' downward). If you had a Keyboard Cover, it won't fit now, so you can't replace it. I encourage you to find something to cover the exposed boards.

  • Turn on the Replicator; the LCD display should come up normally, and the green led on the LCD ESD board should glow (though that's probably going to be hard to see.) Turn off the Replicator. Skip to step 13.

  • Remove the Front Panel and unplug the LCD ribbon cable; the LCD board can stay mounted.

  • This part gets ugly. The LCD ESD board, when mounted on the LCD board, extends into the front of the Replicator. It is necessary to cut out the vertical between the button and LCD, and cut out a sizable chunk out of the front and floor of the build chamber. Fortunately this will be covered by the Front Panel, and it's rear cover, so it doesn't have to be neat; but I'm sure you can do better than I did. (See picture). I grabbed a handy jig saw; I'm sure a dremel tool with cutoff wheel would be a better choice. Be sure to keep the ribbon cable and the LCD ESD board out of the way when you're cutting. Trim away the aluminum tape as necessary, but most of it (not shown in the picture) can be left in place.

  • Plug the LCD ESD board into the ribbon cable in the orientation shown. It's keyed and will only fit one way.

  • Place the LCD Front Panel in position and plug the ESD LCD board into the LCD board. Let it hang there on the cable for a moment and turn on the Replicator. The LCD display should come up normally, and the green led on the LCD ESD board should glow (though that's probably going to be hard to see.) Turn off the Replicator.

  • Cut a notch in the right side of the Front Panel back cover to route the ground cable out. (Eventually I'll revise that thing to include the notch.) Mount the Front Panel and the back cover.

  • The following step is optional, but encouraged. Remove the bottom cover of the Replicator. Unplug the LCD ribbon cable from the MightyBoard (you don't have to unplug the cable, but I found it easier that way). Place the two halves of the clamp-on ferrite filter around the ribbon cable, and snap on the two plastic caps. They all only fit one way. Plug the cable back in.
    • Betcha can't wait for Part 4.

Bonjour,

J'ai fais ce petit bateau pour répondre au challenge MakeItFloat.

La coque de mon bateau est un peu particulière, elle n'a pas une épaisseur constante. J'ai fais ce choix pour stabilisé mon bateau.
En effet, lors de l'impression de la coque j'ai réglé la densité de ma pièce à 20%, ce qui me permet de capturer de l'air à l'intérieur de la coque.

  • La coque est épaisse en haut, ce qui permet d'améliorer la flottabilité de mon bateau grâce à l'air emprisonné dedans.

  • La coque est plus fine en bas pour éviter de déséquilibrer le bateau

L’aspect extérieur du bateau est encore à travailler, il est juste la pour le plaisir des yeux :)

ps : Il est en cour d'impression, je posterai une photo des différentes pièces et de l'ensemble dès que je les auraient testé.

13.07.2015 :
Je viens de corriger le flanc droit du bateau. L'empreinte était trop important.

18.07.2015
Jai fais une petite vidéo pour vous montrer le modèle.
https://youtu.be/xYI_iFcImF8

Toutes les pièces sont dans le .zip

J'ai essayé de découper les pièces afin de simplifier leur impression.

J'arrangerai ça dans les jours à venir.

title: STAR WARS MSE-6 mouse droid body for 1:24  RC Car chassis

description.text:
MSE-6 Repair droid also known as the mouse droid.
Was first seen in Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope.
I modified my RC chassis to work autonomous using an Arduino and some sensors. (See third picture for inspiration)
But this is not part of this build ;)
What you get here is the body to be placed on an 1:24 RC car chassis.
Which will give you your own controllable mouse droid!
How awesome is that !?

https://www.dropbox.com/s/uqwr7o0uq7lfykb/MSE-6%20Instructions.pdf?dl=0

Remove the original body from your RC car.
To attach the body to the chassis you will have to build your own holder.
But hey! This is absolutely easy!
Two wodden bars and some hotglue should do the trick ;)

Litte hint: once assembled "break" the corners with sand paper or a file...this will look much more like the original ;)

Have fun building

The mounting holes is made for the T-Motor MN2206 but it's pretty easy to drill holes for other motors, I can make one without the holes if needed.

description.text:
I see a lot of neat designs for prosthetic hands out there, but in order to modify them for different size, one will need to be able to do some pretty fancy CAD work. So I am starting a project (contributors are welcomed!) to make a design that is:

  1. easy to print
  2. made of elements that can be used to assemble for different sizes by gluing standard spacers.
  3. adaptable (eventually) to electronics.
  4. modular enough to replace partial fingers, full fingers, or full hand.
    I'm using Sketchup for the CAD work, and will be printing out on a Prusa I3.

i just added a foot for an actual o-ring (size =11/16"x 7/16"x 1/8")

added a oring style cutout foot v2.
i added a ninjaflex cutout foot as requested.

i decided to create adjustable feet for the duplicator i3 to get rid of the rocking motion mine gets while sitting on my desk.
and also i have read that other people had wanted adjustable feet to level off there printers.
it just slips on the frame so you can place them where ever you want and have as many as you want to level off your machine

im printing up 6 pairs right now and will post pictures when finnished.

i dont do ninjaflex yet but some asked for models.

comments.text:
Awesome design the mounts and feet printed beautifully, im amazed how well the threads work.
I opted to go with the ninja flex cap versions, the cap itself though is incredibly tricky to print not because of the design but because ninjaflex is insanely difficult to print.
My settings were: 0.1mm layer height
25%infill
240 extruder temp
60 bed temp
Printed on clean bare glass
15mm/s print speed
Disable retraction all together
Travel speed 100mm/s
Also changed my skirt to 5 lines to build pressure.
They are still printing now but are looking good, but they do look a little small we will see how they fit.
Thanks again.

Som un grup d’estudiants d’un curs de disseny per impressores 3d que ha fabricat una peça per a persones que tenen poca mobilitat a la mà i que vulguin jugar a ping-pong.
Amb aquesta peça ajudem a aquestes persones a tenir un suport de mobilitat més elevat del que tenen habitualment.
La peça consisteix en varies peces, dos de les quals col·locarem als dits a una mà, tant de la dreta com de la esquerra, amb el que s’ajuda el moviment de pinça, i aquestes dues peces es col·locarien en les pales de ping pong.
Les possibles actualitzacions podrien ser una anella pel canell, per augmentar la subjecció o unes frontisses per a fer més fàcil la seva col·locació.

title: T-Bone Racig RPM A-Skid Back Plate

description.text:
This is a modified version of T-Bone Racings A-Skid plate clamps for the Traxxas Slash 4x4 RPM A-Arms.

After my first run with the T-Bone A-Skids I noticed one of the backer plate had broken after I had driven my RC around for about half an hour. Might be when I hit a small rock of insignificant size at slow speed.

So I had a closer look on the design and I would say it has 2 major flaws. First off the cutout in it produces 90 degree angles, and that's a weak spot. Second it wasn't long enough to join up with the skid itself, so tightening the screws too much and the clamp would start to bend.

This design replaces the TBR Part Nr: MPN Y036
Print, use a M4 tap for the holes and mount it on your car.

author: winand

description.text:
The United States 2016 Presidential Election is gearing up to be a hotly contested one with wildly contrasting candidates ready to decisively debate the issues. Whether or not you think Hillary Clinton is the right candidate for the job this *first ever 3D-printable** logo for a Presidential Candidate is sure to spark some conversation!

The H Logo

With it's future facing red arrow the 'H' logo stands as a exemplary case study on the ability of design to solicit emotion, discussion and thought. Simple enough to be immediately recognized, sturdy enough to stand on it's own and abstract enough for virtually limitless application. It has only been a few months since the Clinton Campaign first unveiled the 'H' logo and it has already manifested in a variety of clever and imaginative ways.

*As the first 3D printable logo for a Presidential Candidate, this object puts a unique 21st Century twist on the historical tradition of regular citizens producing Presidential Propaganda in their homes

There are three versions available for download solid, two part and dual extrusion. For each you will need blue and red filament.

Hillary 2016 - Solid
Begin by printing this version in blue filament. When the top layer of the H finishes printing and the printer begins to exclusively print the arrow, pause the machine and change to your red filament. When the print is done you will have a beautiful solid two toned Hillary 2016 logo.

Hillary 2016 - Two Part
This version prints in two separate pieces. Print the H in blue filament, the arrow in red filament and assemble the two by press fitting the arrow into the blue H. For a permanent bond use a little adhesive when assembling.

Hillary 2016 - Dual Extrusion
For this version import both models into your slicer, assign the extruder with red filament to the arrow and the extruder with the blue to the H. Let it print and enjoy your fully dual-colored 'Hillary 2016 Logo'

comments.text: Exactly what I hoped for, discussion! In graphic design a 'right pointing arrow' has historical origins as a 'future' pointing arrow. Historically timelines have been dated from left to right: the oldest date is placed all the way to the left, dates are then sequentially placed one at a time working to the right. Finally when we reach the modern era on our timeline, a right pointing arrow is drawn to signify the on going existence of the timeline into the future.

I didn't like the way the z-endstop was clamped to the smooth Z-rod so I've build my own easy-to-level-Z-parts.

You have to print my z-rodholder to screw the endstop in and my z-axis LM8UU Bolt part to put a M4 nut into it and screw a M4 screw through it.

If you wish you could print my M4 hex nut holder for better rotating the screw by hand.

title: Lynxmotion Crazy2Fly Quadcopter Feet + Prop Guards

description.text:
If you've got the Lynxmotion Crazy2Fly quad frame, you might want some feet (landing gear?) and propeller guards. I designed + printed some for me, but maybe you want them too?

The feet should work anywhere you've got a 3mm bolt going into a 6mm hex standoff, so they will likely work on other quad frames. The propeller guards are designed to fit pretty specifically into the C2F frame.

The picture of the feet is version 0.3, but I've uploaded v0.4 to Thingiverse. I'm waiting for all of my 0.3s to break before I put the 0.4s on the quad :)

If you have an Onshape account, here are the parametric versions of the models:

  • Quad Foot
  • Prop Guard

Update 2015.07.10: I've uploaded versions of the prop guard that should work for 5", 6", and 7" props.

Update 2015.07.13: I've added an 8" prop version. I made the walls 3.5mm by default in that version so that they'll be a little sturdier.

Update 2015.07.27: I added a 6" prop version that's much sturdier, using fillets and rounded edges which adds some strength.

description.text:
I made the table top of the table in my camper van foldable,
so i can make it bigger or smaller to suit my needs.
The type of table top is also often used in Marine Yachts.
Often the 'wings' of these tables need support when deploid.
I used 15x15x1.5mm aluminium bars to make this happen.
The 3d printed parts are endcaps with a 1mm raise at one side, U formed 'glide'brackets and some rounded end caps eliminating sharp edges.
I printed al these parts in ABS

This device is for use in intratracheal injections in mice.

I am trying to make a low cost 4 wheel rover, and thought that a nice and simple way to do it would involve laser cutting acrylite and then bending it into a box shape.

The original plan was to use OpenSCAD for this, but I'm a bit rusty with it and I really wanted to get something in my hands as soon as possible. :) Maybe later!

There are mounting holes already designed in for a NEMA17 stepper motor. I also have M5 holes there in case I need to stiffen up the structure with OpenBuilds 20x40 aluminum extrusions. The top of the plate has several M3 holes for allowing me to zip tie electronics and other gear to the platform.

I also modeled a jig to ensure that, during bending, the proper clearances are there to mount the stepper motors.

I don't know how well this will work, but once I get the platform cut, I'll post up pictures of it with Vex wheels and motors mounted.

EDIT - I cut this part today out of 1/8" acrylic instead of 1/4" acrylite. I think 1/8" is good enough. It came out well. The motor "jig" I made doesn't really help at all. I mounted a couple of my NEMA 17 steppers and also mounted my Vex wheels, using my Vex wheel adapter here on Thingiverse. Now I just have to order a few more motors!

Setting the record straight on the 44th president of the US, who was entrusted with the Nobel peace price in 2009 just before bombing Afghanistan, Libia, Somalia, Pakistan, Yemen, Irak, and Syria. His administration armed ISIS and bombed them later, destabilize Ukraine thus world peace and tried to coup Castro and Maduro through Zunzuneo and Hip Hop bands.

Collectible

Afghanistan

The first country attacked by the EE.UU. in the 21st century. Tens of thousand people perished in this prolonged occupation. EE.UU. lost 2200 military and more than 20,000 were injured, plus an undetermined number of "contractors" injured and neglected. Leaving Afghanistan was one of the promises made by Mr. Obama during campaign, but until 2015 the end of military intervention in Afghanistan has only been a stunt, almost like a mantra several times repeated by Mr. Obama in mass media, but in fact the EE.UU. army continues its occupation and most likely it will continue through 2015 and 2016. Despite what Mr. Obama say, what Mr. Obama do is clearly the opposite and its reflected on his own orders: "Mr. Obama's order issued November 2014 allows American forces to carry out missions against the Taliban and other militant groups threatening American troops or the Afghan government, a broader mission than the president described to the public earlier this year, according to several administration, military and congressional officials with knowledge of the decision. The new authorization also allows American jets, bombers and drones to support Afghan troops on combat missions" as stated by The NYT.

Yemen

In October 2000, 17 EE.UU. marines where killed in a suicide attack by al Qaeda against the USS Cole stationed in Aden port (with stinky resemblance of Lusitania and Gulf of Tonkien incident ). In 2010, Mr Obama placed Anwar al-Awlaki, an American imam and allegedly Al Qaeda regional commander, in the list of people the CIA could kill, and so they did using a drone in 2011, along with his son the next day. In 2013 Human Rights Watch documented 6 drone attacks carried out since 2009, identifying 82 casualties which 57 of them were civilians, including children, stating that drone strikes kill more civilians than EE.UU. is willing to admit. In 2014, at least 68 allegedly Afghan militia were murdered in Yemen consequence of an "unprecedented air campaign".

Irak and Syria

In 2003, former secretary of state Collin Powell lied to the United Nations claiming that Sadam Hussein regime had access to "weapons of mass destruction". Later, this claims where considered to be wrongful and even Powell had to recognize it. But that doesn't prevented the Bush administration to conduct a large scale operation that coupe Hussein 3 weeks later. This occupation lead to the later rising of the so called Islamic State, or ISIS, first giving entre to the Sunni fundamentalist force, al-Qaeda in Iraq, which had not existed prior to the U.S. invasion. Al-Qaeda in Iraq would eventually become ISIS, as explained by Robert Freeman. The second step in ISIS's creation, continues the historian, was the U.S. campaign to overthrow Bashar al-Assad in Syria. The third step in ISIS's creation came when EE.UU. organized Saudi Arabia and Turkey to fund and support the proto-ISIS rebels in Syria. Recall that 15 of the 19 identified 9/11 hijackers were Saudis? In short, Sunnis living under the Shi'ite-dominated Iraqi state would rather have Sunni (ISIS) than Shi'ite masters, religious adversaries the U.S. left in power when it was defeated in Iraq. So then again, with the "evildoers" in place it has been bombing as usual.

Pakistan

Drone attack in Pakistan started during George Bush administration, but intensified under Mr. Obama term. Accordingly with the Bureau of Investigative Journalism, EE.UU. launched 390 drone attacks since 2004, 339 took place during Mr. Obama regime. This attacks murdered 4000 people, at least 1000 were civilians. Nawaz Sharif, Pakistan prime minister told Mr. Obama in 2013 that "drone attacks is not only violence against our regional integrity, but also undermines our efforts to eradicate terrorism".

Somalia

In 2007 supported by former Somalia president, Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, EE.UU. launched air attacks against Al Qaeda, who were allegedly responsible of the attacks on EE.UU. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. Sporadic attacks are still performed now a days, although not frequently.

Libia

Most bombing on Libia against Muamar Gadafi were perpetrated by European Union and NATO, but it was EE.UU. who inspired them and supported them in the first strikes. In 2011 Mr. Obama sent an ultimatum to Gadafi forcing him to stop the military efforts against rebels, and reestablishing water, gas and electricity supplies in all zones in the country. The Wall Street Journal documented that CIA participated actively in the search of Gadafi when he escaped. 3 years ahead, the situation in Libia is not better, and the political chaos continues.

The Collectible

In order to set the record straight, we produced the "Bombama" collectible, portraying the 44th president of EE.UU. defined by his actions, not his words, speech and propaganda.

The collectible is 3D printed in ABS and hand painted. The face of the collectible does not resemble much to Mr. Obama, due to the "unexplainable" recent 3D scanning of Mr. Obama body and face, so in order to avoid legal claims we have depicted him close enough, so you get the idea.

comments.text: En mi caso es rosca paso 2 y le puse 1600, se calcula con ésta fórmula, pasos por mm = pasos del motor por vuelta x micropasos del pololu / paso de la rosca. Entonces es en mi caso 200 porque el nema 17 tiene 200pasos por vuelta, y 16 porque es la resolución del pololu y 2 porque es el paso de mi rosca (da igual el diametro) ----> 200x16/2=1600

description.text:
Waterproof Remote Control for selfrecovery winch.
This thing is based on an inexpensive chinese remote control, I found it on Aliexpress: http://www.aliexpress.com/snapshot/6682475801.html

I desoldered a stock antenna and replaced it with just a flexible copper wire 1.5 sq.mm. Length is about 290mm. The link range is 60..100m. The top and bottom parts are sealed using a neutral gasket maker, you can easily find it in your local auto store. Do not forget to cover PCB using any available clear. I applied two layers. Seal the antenna hole using a hotmelt glue. I enforced my antenna with a pair of nylon stripes. Also added a shrinkable tube.

Before printing please rotate all parts bottom up, so you will get nicer surfaces and better sealing. Top and bottom need support.

For russian readers: http://www.chipmaker.ru/topic/158155/

UPD: added a ring and magnet holders for round magnets 20x3mm.

description.text: I created this to be used on top of a glass when I want to squeeze some fresh lemon juice into it (and avoid choking on the seeds!). Thanks to the teacher next to me who helped me create a better design for it;)

So, I’ve created a spool mount mounting bracket to change orientation of the spool, I created filament ties that snap on the material reel, I created feet to keep your machine from shifting and I created USB cable ties to route your USB cable. Now I have added a Spool Hub. The new narrow spools of material don’t fit well with the OEM spool mount. I’ve had a couple walk right off the OEM Spool Mount. So, I created this simple hub to place next to the spool. It keeps the spool on and I never get this failure anymore. All five of these designs are now uploaded for you use. All five have enhanced my printing experience. Worth the time to make and install! Thanks, Reamo

title: Prusa i3 Y-Carraige belt holder V3

description.text:
NB NOTE: If you having problems with printing my designs please download them again. When we were printing them for my printer we found that some of them had errors on the mesh. Asking Nettfab to auto repair broke some of them even more. No M3 holes in the top of the base pieces for instance. I had to fix every error manually and the upload all the parts again. I believe they are now all fixed. If you find any other issues please let me know so that I can fix them.

After I drew up the first version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:912217 I sat looking at it and started to wonder why we still fold the belt back and clamp it as well.

There used to be a reason for folding it back and cable tying it. It was because the early belt clamps were not very efficient and the belt would come loose if not tied back. These days we are only doing it because that is how we always did it. (That is unless you are still using an old belt holder design, then you MUST still tie it back)

We have moved on from that with new belt types where the teeth are designed not to slip or shear off. With the belt clamped down between two parts with screws holding it tight there is absolutely no chance for the belt to come loose. The force needed to tear the belt lose from such a clamp will turn you printer into a pile of junk spaghetti before the belt will come loose.

So I started to redesign the belt clamp, V2 was good but it was over engineered for me and I thought I could simplify it more. So I did and here we have V3.

We will be doing a test print of the belt clamps and base tomorrow to see if the new clamp part will print in good enough quality to satisfy me, and it takes a lot to satisfy me.

The belt holder is about the same total height (the belt is still at exactly the same height as the standard Prusa i3 design) as the previous versions but the screws are now recessed into the clamps so the total height of it has been further reduced. The teeth profile in the clamps are GT2 - 2mm specific. Also the spacing between the clamp and base are for the same belt, it will not be crushed but will be firmly clamped.

Use two M3 by 10mm Allen Cap screws on each clamp. There are M3 thread printed into the four screw holes. If the screws fits to tight just run a standard M3 tap through it. I left the holes open on the bottom as well so that a tap can go through easily.

If this gives you more ideas go ahead and improve it even more. I would like to see what you will come up with.

Cheers

Update 2015-07-08:
Added a version of the base with captured nuts for those who do not know when tight is tight enough :) You will have to use M3 by 12mm Allen cap screws however as the nut placing for M3x10 was to close to the top for my comfort. A M3 nut measures 5.4mm on the flats and 2.4mm high. I made the cavities 5.5mm by 2.5mm. If you find that it is to tight drop me a comment and I will make it slightly larger. Or if you know what a good size for the nut cavity is also please drop me a comment

Update 2015-07-20:
Found that some of the files were not manifold, so I pushed them all through Nettfab

Update 2016-02-01
Added the source files in both dxf and stp formats

title: Vision Flipping Glasses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
You've probably heard the story about the artist who wore mirrored goggles flipping his vision upside down for a few days. After a while his brain also flipped correcting his perspective. When he finally took off the glasses at the end of the experiment he found that his own native vision was upside down. Cool eh?
Here's a chance to try. The mechanism of these is articulated by looking down into the mirrored panel. You see there a flipped version of the world. Unfortunately your cone of vision is pretty limited. It's intended to be laser cut on .11 mirrored acrylic (mirrored side down, please)which is often labeled as 1/8". You'll also need 4-40 shcs and nuts. Washers completely optional... I can't remember why I included them in the design.
Just cut the acrylic laser style (mirrored side down) and assemble until it looks like the pictures. Couldn't be too much simpler.

description.text:
We approximate the volume below z=16-x^2-2y^2 and above the square [0,2]x[0,2] with a double Riemann sum. We take the [0,2]x[0,2] square and subdivide it into 16 smaller squares, then create a rectangular prism by choosing the height to be the function value in the center of the square. The height was also scaled down by a factor of four. The resulting collection looks like a bunch of french fries!

Together with Volume by 64 & no French Fries, this shows how a double Riemann sum can approximate a volume. (See https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:917118 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:918151.)

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell ('17).

This object was made on a MakerBot2X. We used the following settings:
2 shells
0.20mm layer height
10% infill (hexagonal pattern)
No supports
raft off
iPad Air (or other 7.5 mm Depth Tablet) Stand/Holder. Made to stay up on a bed or other moving surface.

title: Melodyian - Primid Robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a printable Melodyian. When combined with an Arduino and other electronic components it can be turned into a remote-controlled Melodyian musical robot! Check out the complete Instructable here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Musical-Melodyian-MIDI-Robot/

Alternatively, it can act as a friendly Melodyian "objet d'art" - a curious interstellar traveler always at the ready to greet you with a friendly stare and calming presence. Print it, decorate it, share it with your friends, and take it with you wherever your cosmic travels may lead.

Links to videos and photos of these Melodyian robots below:
https://vimeo.com/100353397
https://vimeo.com/118353426
https://vimeo.com/114522541
https://instagram.com/musical_melodyians/

If you make your own Melodyian, take a picture and let us know on Instagram! @musical_melodyians #melodyianrobot

Important note - Make sure you scale these pieces to INCHES before printing, not millimeters. These pieces often initialize in mm units when first loaded into printing applications like MakerWare, but don’t be fooled! Make sure they’re scaled to inches!

All the pieces have been designed to friction fit together and we've tested extensively using ABS plastic. We recommend printing with ABS plastic, but PLA should work too.

––––––––– Printing Instructions –––––––––

If you have ambitions to turn your Melodyian into an Arduino-based musical robot, print these pieces in the following quantities:

• Primid_Base – 1
• Primid_Connector-Loop – 8 connectors (1 print of this file)
• Primid_Connector-Peg – 48 pegs total (10 duplicates of this file = 50 pegs)
• Primid_Eye-Large – 4
• Primid_Eye-Med – 4
• Primid_Eye-Small – 4
• Primid_Face-A – 2
• Primid_Face-B – 2
• Primid_InnerMount-Risers – 4 pieces (1 print of this file)
• Primid_InnerMount-Surface – 1

If you wish to print a simpler Melodyian sculpture, you can save yourself some plastic by only printing these pieces in the following quantities:

• Primid_Base – 1
• Primid_Connector-Loop – 8 connectors (1 print of this file)
• Primid_Connector-Peg – 40 pegs total (8 duplicates of this file = 40 pegs)
• Primid_Eye-Large – 4
• Primid_Eye-Med – 4
• Primid_Eye-Small – 4
• Primid_Face-A – 2
• Primid_Face-B – 2

Once you're done printing all the pieces, mosey on over to our Instructable page to see how to paint and assemble the finished Melodyian robot!

http://www.instructables.com/id/Musical-Melodyian-MIDI-Robot/step18/Paint-and-Decorate-your-Melodyian/

Experimenting with ninjaflex i found that i could not print with the springy filament without it buckling inside of the extruder housing and making a mess. This part simply provides support from the gears to where it enters the hotend. I am using this extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:728158) but i may work with others also.

To install this part the stepper motor and filament must be removed. After the motor has been removed the support piece can be placed directly on top of the hotend. reassemble with part in place and then reload filament. I also drilled out the hole in the guide to give a smoother hole to hopefully prevent friction against the filament. Good Luck!

description.text:
We approximate the volume below the surface z=16-x^2-2y^2 and above the square [0,2]x[0,2] with a double Riemann sum. We take the [0,2]x[0,2] square and subdivide it into 64 smaller squares, then create a rectangular prism by choosing the height to be the function value in the center of the square. The height was also scaled down by a factor of four. The resulting collection looks like a bunch of french fries!

Together with Volume by 16 & no French Fries, this shows how a double Riemann sum can approximate a volume. (See https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:917032 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:918151.)

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell ('17).

This object was made on a MakerBot2X. We used the following settings:
2 shells
0.20mm layer height
10% infill (hexagonal pattern)
No supports
raft off
It´s only a little bunker but I like it. You can put a led inside it.

Here is a set of coordinate axes for 3-dimensional space. The ends of the axes have been labeled with x, y, and z. They have been made so that many of the models (Wedges 1 & 2, Volumes by French Fries) will fit into them.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell ('17).

This object was made on a MakerBot2X. We used the following settings:
2 shells
0.20mm layer height
10% infill (hexagonal pattern)
No supports
raft off

This Steinmetz solid is the solid common to three right circular cylinders of equal radii intersecting at right angles. It pairs nicely with the Three Intersection Cylinders object (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:917132).

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Emily Jaekle ('16). See http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/12/three-intersecting-cylinders/.

This object was made on a MakerBot2X. We used the following settings:
2 shells
0.20mm layer height
10% infill (hexagonal pattern)
Color matched supports
Raft off

The top half of the solid looked fantastic. However, on one small part of the bottom, it looked like the plastic had cooled too quickly. (This may not be a problem with other printers.)

We then printed the object with a different orientation. There were fewer problems with this build. Overall the object was a success.

Solution, if you have a field that will be rendered with text(), use text(str(input)) to force it to be rendered as a string. Otherwise if an integer is put in it will be put into a variable as an integer, and text() will not render it

Testing customizer... finally found the issue, this is an example of it
lopsided_cup by Susan [created on 3DTin]

This model shows three right circular cylinders of equal radii intersecting at right angles. It pairs nicely with the Steinmetz 3-cylinder solid (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:917124).

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Emily Jaekle ('16). See http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/12/three-intersecting-cylinders/

author: JohnNotKen

title: 20x20 V Wheel Bracket for Magnetic Conversion

description.text:
Convert a standard 20x20 frame extrusion to a V
Wheel, magnetic arm system at minimum expense. Spheres are 5/8".

Using standard 24mm V wheels on standard 20x20 extrusion can be done by printing one complete Carriage Set for each tower. The carriages are set for 5/8" Spheres and utilize a belt drive. The photos show basic construction. The lower belt attachment is done with one 6mm wide spacer held by a small metal screw (1/2" long) directly into the carriage. The upper mount uses the same screw size to a narrower spacer and goes to the belt with an adjustable tie wrap. The wheels are mounted with asymmetric spacers, the smaller one to the front or inside of the delta and the taller one to the rear. This allows the front carriage piece to ride on the 20x20 for extra stability (room for a piece of slippery tape for smooth travel) and will keep the rear rear carriage from hitting the 20x20 on the back side.
Note: things fit tightly, but the carriage should move pretty freely once everything is assembled. You will need 5mm screws (or 10-24, US) and everything may need a touch of finesse for the best fit. I epoxied the spheres in place and put a dab of CA on the flags. Works perfectly so far....

The 3rd version of my vibration damper. It is much easier to assemble than v2. It is as strong, as effective and 2 parts instead of 5.

Enjoy and please comment.

description.text: This is a simple mount for extruded aluminum rails to mount led strips with 3m sticky tape

I printed these with .2mm layers at 10% rect. infill.

Bought led 8" stip from the auto parts store that has 3m tape of the back these just made a place at the top of my printer to add light.

This is a rather specific base for a message torch. It's designed to fit an Ocean Vodka bottle with a Spark Core / Particle Photon beneath. It's a two-piece print and the top should fit snugly into the bottom.

You can find more project information in the original forum thread (note that I am not the original poster--merely a copycat).

1. Print base-bottom.stl and base-top.stl.
  2. Put your favorite microcontroller in base-bottom.stl. There is a side hole for power/USB/whatever (I used a DC barrel connector for power).
  3. Feed necessary power and control wires through the top.
  4. Connect wires to LED strip.
  5. Place base-top.stl into base-bottom.stl, aligning the cutout in the top to match the bottom so the wires will fit through.
  6. Plug in and enjoy!

comments.text: The bevel on the pin doesn't have to be all the way around, just facing the direction of assembly. I would suggest on the underside so you can print it without support material.  There should be a slight matching bevel on the top inside part in front of the hole. The pin can probably be a larger radius it looks like it might have too much play. I'd add an arch under the long cross member up top to reduce the size of the bridging. When I get home I'll try to print one. I've been looking for a cable chain. And if you look at the STL from above you'll see that the pins can't actually fit inside the holes they are too far away. Open your modeller up and put two in the space and line them up as they would be assembled, you'll see what I mean. But it is manifold and it will slice. I hope you were serious about wanting feedback.. I'm not trying to be mean. I think I just over analyze stuff.

From the game Splatoon, this is a replica of the training dummies from Sheldon's weapon test area. This model is to scale with the Splatoon Amiibos, so they'll make great accessories for them. Files include the line pattern and X pattern dummies, and one blank dummy.

Update 8/3/15- Added Sticky98's version of Zero in parts (Zero.zip)

An Amiibo based on Zero's appearance as a trophy in Super Smash Brothers for Wii U. Credit to MrMagitwo and Arshes for his Amiibo base model. I recommend that you should use it over the Mii Swordfighter Amiibo chip with the zero costume.

Shoutout to Sticky98 for printing the model and showing me how it went so I can make this new model!

Arshes:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:778886
MrMagitwo:https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:839898

For the production of this Amiibo, I have used the Megaman, Pac-Man, Palutena, and Luigi Amiibos for Measurements

I made it by using 3d Builder from Microsoft to seperate the model and simplify the parts, Google Sketchup to fix Zero's Hair, and Tinkercad to put on the attachment parts for the hair and his hand.

To put the model together

1 Print out everything

2 Put the sword and hand into the socket on his arm

3 Put the hair into the socket behind his body

4 glue the figure on the amiibo stand (optional)

Walla! You have a Zero amiibo!

title: Ninja Turtle Action Figure - Individual Files

description.text: Kudos to myxibrium for the original model and stl files. I have little luck with printing a bed of multiple pieces. I cut up the stl files into individual files for ease of use. Hit up the original poster if you enjoy his model. I used Green Tglase from Taulman3D to print mine ;)

comments.text: What layer height and shell thickness is that? I use the white, red, and blue tglase, but i haven't used the green because people say its not as "stunning", this looks great though. Try using XTC-3D on it, the hard epoxy shell. It takes a few trys to get it on there perfectly, but it makes tglase look incredible. Especially the red, it turns into a bright ruby color and if you make it solid with low layer heights, it will have a "cat's eye" look inside of it.
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: I used .2mm layer height and 2 parameter shells 4 top and 4 bottom. I get great results printing tglase with that config. I have used XTC-3D before and its pretty awesome stuff. Taulman3D has a blog called 'Hacking Tglase' where they describe the lens affect caused by filling in the concave area with XTC-3D. Its a pretty cool read. Also, i have found that each of the colors of Tglase look great. The trick is to keep consistent print temp of 245 C. That works the best for me. I also keep the print bed at 75 degrees and it sticks great on plan glass... almost too great... i have had to add a layer of PVA glue on it to add a buffer, because it can pull divots out of plan glass... its tough stuff.
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text:
As for print temp, that's a bit too hot (degradation is at 248C) so my guess is your turtle is pretty brittle. Will crack before bending. Use temps below 240C (yes that 5C does have a big effect). If your printer can't print it at that temp, you have a nozzle clog or just need replacements from wear. I use twin E3D V6's. But it could be that you are printing too fast. At 0.2mm, you should only get about 30mm/s max, before it doesn't lay down properly. You are also hurting material clarity. You might think got means more clear (better fusing) but it doesn't. Tglase is more clear at slower speeds and low temps. At tall layers... Like 80% of your nozzle diameter. In my case, .35mm, and it requires speeds down around 6mm-15mm\s. Bridges are 6.
You will find at low layer heights (0.1) you will see clogs and won't work peroperly, the concepts break down at that height because of how long the molecules are and how the bonds work (they don't like to rearrange) and if you slow down, you bake the filament. Lowest ive got was .15 before quality loss. I've been working with it for almost 3 years and learned a ton of tricks.
Try making a micro gear heart with it. Took me almost a year to get the technique dialed in. There's a very small window of settings that work. To my knowledge, only 2 solid Tglase micro gear hearts exist right now. I was the second to finish. First one was an old retired engineer, you can find his print on here under "working micro gear heart", its red.
comments.author: GoriNation

comments.text: Try using Slic3r and set top and bottom layer to concentric. Set an odd number of bottom layers (3,5,7 etc - I use 5) find a model with a round bottom, print just the base layers. Peel off, and look at it as if it were a CD. Make the reflection spin. You'll notice something I call a lense clover, where the light bends and appears to move. This happens because of Tglase's optical (fiber optic) properties and can look amazing when coated with XTC.
comments.author: GoriNation
